A BSTRACT Background: Second-hand smoke (SHS) accounts for 0.9 million deaths and 24 million disability adjusted life years annually. SHS exposure has been associated to a wide range of diseases thus far, with the majority of studies focused on the link between SHS exposure and the development of cardiovascular disorders or lung cancer. Objectives: The objectives of the study were to estimate the prevalence of SHS exposure and identify its sociodemographic correlates among nonsmokers and also to assess knowledge and attitude toward SHS among nonsmokers in adults. Methodology: The study included 400 subjects where 200 each was recruited from rural and urban areas. Twenty were selected randomly using survey registers from each of the ten subcentes from rural areas. From urban areas, 66 subjects were selected randomly from three urban health posts. Data collection included information that was recorded on a predesigned, pretested semistructured interview schedule. Results: The prevalence of second-hand exposure at home was found to be 44% and 54% in urban and rural areas, respectively, whereas at workplaces, it was found to be 50.5% and 60.9%. It also reflected SHS exposure at home is significantly associated with study area, age category, occupation, and education, while SHS exposure at workplaces is significantly associated with occupation, education, and socioeconomic scale. Conclusion: The study highlights a high prevalence of second-hand smoke exposure among nonsmokers in both rural and urban areas, particularly at home and workplaces. Sociodemographic factors such as age, occupation, education, and socioeconomic status significantly influence SHS exposure. These findings underscore the need for targeted public health interventions, including awareness campaigns and policy enforcement, to reduce SHS exposure and protect nonsmokers from its harmful effects. Second-hand tobacco smoke is also referred to as ETS. Third-hand smoke occurs when tobacco smoke leaves residual nicotine and other chemicals on indoor surfaces, skin, fur, and furniture, even after the air has cleared.[ 1 Side-stream smoke releases five times as much carbon monoxide and twice as much tar into the air as compared to what enters a smoker’s lungs.[ 2 3 4 5 6 Second-hand smoke (SHS) accounts for 0.9 million deaths and 24 million disability adjusted life years (DALYs) annually. SHS exposure has been associated to a wide range of diseases thus far, with the majority of studies focused on the link between SHS exposure and the development of cardiovascular disorders or lung cancer. SHS increases the risk of heart disease and lung cancer by 25–30% and 20–30%, respectively, in people who are exposed to it.[ 7 8 9 10 11 12 Though there is general awareness among public about ill effects of SHS exposure through legislation of COTPA Act, strict implementation of various rules and penalization are not done at the ground level. In a state like Haryana, hookah usage has been seen in many houses and is used as a customary practice irrespective of their social and economic status. There are many literature studies about the prevalence of usage of hookah and other tobacco products, but studies about SHS exposure are very limited. The objectives of the study were to estimate the prevalence of SHS exposure and identify its sociodemographic correlates among nonsmokers. Also, this study assessed knowledge and attitude toward SHS among nonsmokers in adults of age 18–60 years in district Rohtak, Haryana. Material and Methods After obtaining ethical clearance, this descriptive cross-sectional study was conducted in rural and urban field practice areas attached to the Department of Community Medicine, Pt. BD Sharma PGIMS, Rohtak. The study was conducted over a period of 12 months (2022–2023) from the date of commencement. Nonsmoking adults in the age group of 18–60 years who were willing to participate and residing in the study area for more than 6 months were included. Study subjects who were using any form of tobacco including smokeless tobacco and those who were severely ill or have severe mental illness were excluded from the study. Sample size was calculated taking prevalence as 51% second hand exposed in home in urban areas from Global Adult Tobacco Survey (GATS) conducted in Haryana 2016–2017[ 13 Figure 1 Figure 1 Flowchart of Methodology A questionnaire was designed for the study which consisted of information regarding sociodemographic profiles of study subjects and information regarding SHS exposure of the study participants from the GATS, which was administered to the study subjects. It is the standardized tool and is freely available in the public domain. The questionnaire also consisted of information about knowledge and attitude toward SHS exposure which were in the form of Yes/No questions and Likert scale, respectively. The investigator met the subject to explain the purpose of the study with patient information sheets, and a written consent was sought to seek their cooperation before the study. Help of health workers/ASHA/Anganwadi workers at the time of the interview was taken. The purpose of the study was explained in the study subject’s vernacular language in detail. The confidentiality of the information obtained was maintained. Data were collected, compiled, and entered in the MS Excel sheet. Analysis was carried out using MS Excel with appropriate statistical tests wherever applicable. However, this percentage became lower as 49.5% of participants expressed that they would ask “people” around them to put out their cigarettes and 49.75% of participants expressed that they would not chat with people while they are smoking. Discussion The present study was conducted to find out the prevalence of SHS exposure among nonsmokers in adults and identify various sociodemographic correlates of SHS exposure. This study assessed knowledge and attitude among study participants about SHS exposure. The prevalence of second-hand exposure at home was found to be 44% and 54% in urban and rural areas, respectively. Similar trends were seen with GATS 2 India[ 13 et al 14 15 et al 16 In the present study, the prevalence of second-hand exposure at workplace was found to be 50.5% and 60.9% in urban and rural areas, respectively. This was in accordance with GATS 2 India[ 13 15 et al 16 et al 17 In the present study, it is found out that among those who visited the public places, 45.8% of them were exposed to SHS in government offices or buildings, 18.6% of them were exposed to SHS in health care facilities, 39.8% of them were exposed to SHS in restaurants, 84% of them were exposed to SHS in night clubs/bars, 50.8% of them were exposed to SHS during public transportation, and 26.2% of them were exposed to SHS in university buildings. In contrast to our study, GATS 2 India[ 13 et al et al 18 19 From the present study, it is understood that though study participants were aware that SHS exposure is harmful and contains substances known to be toxic, the knowledge about exact ill effects caused by SHS like risk of developing lung cancer and heart diseases was really lacking. Also, knowledge about risk of pregnant women having harmful effects when exposed to SHS is alarmingly low. Regarding attitude toward SHS exposure, the participants in the present study exhibited favorable attitude toward parents having no right to smoke around children, banning of cigarette advertisements, and smoking in public places. The majority of them felt helpless in restraining visitors from smoking, and smoking was allowed at some or all parts of their homes. In a state like Haryana, this is expected to be prominent as families are often more culturally conservative and more traditional to ask visitors to put out the cigarette or shy away from a conversation when the visitor starts to smoke. Limitations In this study, SHS exposure was defined as a proxy measure constructed from self-reported home smoking rules and might thus not always reflect real exposure to SHS at home. Also, we could not assess the cumulative effect of SHS exposure. For example, we did not evaluate that how many years the participants were exposed to SHS. Conclusion and Recommendations The present study reflected high prevalence of SHS exposure at home, workplace, and public places among nonsmoking adults of District Rohtak, Haryana. It also reflected SHS exposure at home is significantly associated with study area, age category, occupation, and education, while SHS exposure at workplace is significantly associated with occupation, education, and socioeconomic scale. There is no safe amount of SHS exposure. The home is the main place many children and adults breathe in SHS. Though study participants were aware that SHS exposure is harmful and contains substances known to be toxic, the knowledge about exact ill effects caused by SHS was really lacking. Therefore, education to promote smoke-free homes can be part of campaigns implemented to build public support for smoke-free legislation, which have included messages informing smokers, particularly as parents, of the impact of SHS exposure in the home and have urged them to make their homes smoke-free. The role of the National Tobacco Control Programme is crucial here. It should be expanded in monitoring and evaluation of tobacco control activities, supplemented by periodic surveys beside the enforcement of the law at the district and state levels. There should be stronger public health education and advocacy efforts for the general public about smoke-free legislation to improve compliance and implementation of antitobacco laws.
